relation: Yes (with proper setting of HCLK divider)
title: CPU clock speed constraints
TableContextTimeStampBeforeTable: {3745=This page details the power managment of the Phase 1 Neo1973. Much of it is inapplicable to earlier models., 386=This page tries to describe the various power management features of the Neo1973 Hardware, their states, transitions, etc. First, we start by describing the power states of the individual hardware components. Then we look at it from a System Integration point of view.}
TableContextTimeStampAfterTable: {15963=PIO_2 of the DFBM-CS320 is connected to GPC7 of the s3c2410. PIO_5 of the DFBM-CS320 is connected to GPC5 of the s3c2410. BT_EN of the DFBM-CS320 is connected to GPB5 if the s3c2410. [1], 28168=I played with old ampermeter, old nokia 3110 (as a powersupply) and phase0 neo1973 a bit. It appears to eat 1.02 mW while powered off, 1.02W while booted (backlight on), ~0.51W while sleeping (with backlight on) and 1.4W while loading applications., 29253=The script logs the time, battery voltage, charging current, battery temperature, charging mode, bluetooth-on status, gps-on status, gsm-on status, and backlight brightness numbers. The kernel page claims the charging current is in ma, but that does not appear to be the case for all builds? eg 2.6.21.6-moko10. The battery temperature does not always appear to be in degrees C, either., 15741=The S3C2410 has the EINT0 pin of the S3C2410 connected to the GSM modem, which wakes it on configured events., 16378=If somebody pushes either the Neo1973 Aux Button or the Neo1973 Power Button, the system shall wake up., 7729=The S3C2410 SoC section is an overview of the S3C2410 power states or modes and their capabilities. The S3C2410 has the following modes:}
textBeforeTable: In order to do system-level power managment, we need to introduce state definitions with their according state names. The state names are prefixed by SYS_POWER_. System Power states This is a description of the system-level power management. System Level Fully powered up and operational Normal Holds register data with clock stopped Sleep In this mode, only the supply power is activated Deep Standby JBT6K74 LCM Condition: Vbat > Vlowbat Human-Readable: If main battery voltage > 2.8V (configurable up to 3.4V) Transition from STANDBY to ACTIVE: If ONKEY button is pressed, or RTC Alarm, or EXTON or charger insert or pen-down by touchscreen (we don't use the PMU TS controller) ACTIVE Human-readable: If main battery voltage > 2.7V Condition: Vbat > Vverylowbat STANDBY Human-readable: If main battery voltage < 2.7V and at least backup battery voltage > 1.3V or charger voltage > 2.7V. Condition: Vbat < Vverylowbat && (Vback > Vlowback || Vchgvin > Vlowchg) SAVE Human-Readable: If main battery voltage < 2.7V and backup battery voltage < 1.3V and charger voltage < 2.7V Condition: Vbat < Vverylowbat && Vback < Vlowback && Vchgvin < Vlowchg NOPOWER This is
textAfterTable: On by MODEM_ON to HIGH Optional Deep Standby Off SCRSAVE Screen Saver Active SLOW, IDLE SLEEP On by MODEM_ON to HIGH Optional Optional Off ON Normal active state Active On Normal On by MODEM_ON to HIGH Optional On On, PWM'd brightness Wake-up reasons In the following events, we want the main CPU to be able to be woken up from Power_off (SYS_POWER_SLEEP) state: Events from GSM Incoming phone call Incoming SMS Loss of network signal Implementation The GSM daemon configures the GSM Modem so as to wake the CPU when events happen. The S3C2410 has the EINT0 pin of the S3C2410 connected to the GSM modem, which wakes it on configured events. GPIO from Bluetooth PIO_2 of the DFBM-CS320 is connected to GPC7 of the s3c2410. PIO_5 of the DFBM-CS320 is connected to GPC5 of the s3c2410. BT_EN of the DFBM-CS320 is connected to GPB5 if the s3c2410. [1] Button Press If somebody pushes either the Neo1973 Aux Button or the Neo1973 Power Button, the system shall wake up. Implementation
